KMeans.algo_info: Calculates K clusters represented by a central point that is the mean of all the points in a given cluster
KMeans.algo_usecase: General-purpose, even cluster size, flat geometry, not too many clusters. Metric is Euclidean Dist.

init.param_info: A way to initialise the centers : randomly or kmeans++ (see scikit-learn documentation on kmeans)

n_clusters.param_info: The number of clusters the user wishes to obtain

n_init.param_info: Number of time the k-means algorithm will be run with different centroid seeds. The final results will be the best output of n_init consecutive runs in terms of inertia

max_iter.param_info: Maximum number of iterations of the k-means algorithm for a single run

random_state.param_info: random_state is an optional parameter to specify the seed used by the random number generator

KMedoids.algo_info: KMedoids clustering uses the median value of all the points in a given cluster instead of the mean
KMedoids.algo_usecase: General-purpose, even cluster size, flat geometry, not too many clusters. Metric used is Euclidean Distance

n_clusters.param_info: The number of clusters the user wishes to obtain

AgglomerativeClustering.algo_info: Recursively merges the pair of clusters that minimally increases a given linkage distance (see scikit-learn).
AgglomerativeClustering.algo_usecase:
Many clusters, possibly connectivity constraints + 
Large n_samples and n_clusters

n_clusters.param_info: The number of clusters the user wishes to obtain

affinity.param_info:
Metric used to compute the linkage. Can be 'euclidean', 'l1', 'l2', 'manhattan' or 'cosine'
If linkage is 'ward', only 'euclidean' is accepted.

linkage.param_info:
Which linkage criterion to use : the linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation.
The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion.
- 'ward' minimizes the variance of the clusters being merged.
- average uses the average of the distances of each observation of the two sets.
- complete or maximum linkage uses the maximum distances between all observations of the two sets.
